doc.title: Europe Technology: Semiconductor: Read-across from Nvidia's 2QFY26 results to European Semiaap and Al Infra companies
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Europe Technology Semiconductors Read-across from Nvidias 2QFY26 results to European Semicap and AI Infra companiesEurop_2025-08-28

passages.text: Investigating scope for Gen Al to drive upside for European Semis Ecosystem Explore >

Nvidia (covered by Jim Schneider) reported its 2QFY26 results yesterday post US market close and delivered revenues of \(46.7bn\) (up \(+56\%\) yoy and \(+6\%\) qoq) versus its guidance of \(\) 45bn\(and broadly in - line with Visible Alpha Consensus Data expectations of\) \ \(46.5bn\) . Most relevant to our coverage, its Data Center business reported revenues of \(\) 41bn\(, up\) 5\% \(qoq, as strength in Networking demand was partially offset by a decline in H20 GPU sales and a somewhat slower Blackwell ramp (up \(+17\%\) qoq). As such, large CSPs contributed around \(50\%\) of Nvidia's DC business, and the US semis team believes this highlights a broadening of the company's customer base and adoption of the Blackwell GPUs beyond the traditional Hyperscalers. Furthermore, Nvidia pointed towards continued strength in GPU demand from Sovereign compute capacity build- out and the company expects this sovereign demand to contribute c. \(\) 20bn\(of revenue in CY25 (implying 2x yoy increase). More broadly, we see continued demand from Sovereign build- out as a positive for Nebius given the company is actively expanding its global capacity and offers a\) 20- 25\%\$ lower TCO for customers. Additionally, Nvidia stated that its Rubin platform remains on track for launch in mid- 2026, and all 6 constituent chips of this platform have entered pilot manufacturing. As such, we believe that the positive commentary around the broadening of Al demand, contributions from sovereign buildout and on- track production of the Rubin platform is a positive for the overall leading- edge demand, and below we contextualise the implications of Nvidia's earnings and outlook for the European semicap players ASML (Buy), ASMI (Buy), BESI (Buy), as well as European Al infrastructure provider Nebius (Buy).

Furthermore, Nvidia guided for 3QFY26 revenue of \(\) 54bn\(at the midpoint (up +16\%\) qoq and \(+54\%\) yoy) in - line with cons estimates going into the print. The company highlights that it did not ship any H20 GPUs to China and its outlook for 3QFY26 does not factor in any revenue contributions from China.
- We see the broadening of Al demand beyond the traditional Hyperscalers and

the shipping of Blackwell Ultra platform in the current quarter (which contributed tens of billions in revenue) as a positive near- term readacross for the AI indexed European stocks. While the US government has lifted its ban on shipments of the H20 GPUs and has granted some customer licenses, we note that Nvidia's 3QFY26 guide does not reflect any contributions from China due to continued geopolitical uncertainty. As such, in the scenario where this uncertainty is resolved, Nvidia could ship \(\) 2- 5bn\(of H20 GPUs in 3QFY26 (per Nvidia). More broadly, we believe that the aforementioned demand trends and product traction bodes well for the European semicap names ASML (Buy), ASMI (Buy) and BESI (Buy).

Furthermore, management reiterated that the Rubin platform remains on track for launch in mid 2026, and that the company aims for an annual product launch cadence as it continues to see an increase in AI Inference demand as Reasoning and Agentic AI gain traction across industries. In this vein, we remain positive on European semicap names ASML and ASMI given their tools are of strategic importance to drive incremental node shrinkage to fulfill the performance requirements of these complex AI workloads.

Lastly, management highlighted a continued strong interest in developing Sovereign AI infrastructure, and expects Sovereign AI to contribute c. \(\) 20bn\(revenues in CY25 (implying a c.2x yoy increase). Further, Nvidia highlighted that the European Union plans to invest\) \in 20bn\$ to construct 20 AI gigafactories across France, Germany, Italy and Spain. As such, we view this increasing focus on developing sovereign AI capabilities as a positive for European AI Infrastructure provider Nebius given it is actively expanding its available GPU capacity across the globe (see our recent earnings review note here). Additionally, the company also screens favourably due to its full stack product offering and hardware expertise delivering a lower TCO for its customers (see details in our initiation note here). More broadly, the demand from Sovereign AI is a positive for LT European semi demand in our view.

ASML: We are Buy- rated on ASML with a 12- month price target of €935 based on a 32x 2HCY26+1HCY27 P/E multiple. Key risks to our view and price target include EUV delays, capex cyclicality and unfavourable market share shifts.

ASMI: We are Buy- rated on ASMI with a 12- month price target of €615 based on a 21x 2HCY26+1HCY27E EV/EBITDA multiple. Key risks to our view and price target include worsening of the semi cycle, stronger- than- expected competition and high customer concentration.

BESI: We are Buy- rated on BESI with a 12- month price target of €161 based on a 26x 2HCY26+1HCY27E EV/EBITDA multiple. Key risks to our view and price target include customer spend cyclicality, hybrid bonding adoption delays and increasing competition.

Nebius: We are Buy rated on Nebius with a 12- month price target of \(\) 77\(based on a 6x CY27E EV/Sales multiple. Key risks to our view and price target include competitive pressure from Hyperscalers, slower than expected adoption of AI and reduced visibility from shorter term contracts.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
